abstract.t: The Web Real-Time Communication working group is charged to provide protocol support for direct interactive rich communication using audio, video and data between two peers' web browsers. With in the WebRTC framework, Session Description protocol (SDP) is used for negotiating session capabilities between the peers. Such a negotiation happens based on the SDP Offer/Answer exchange mechanism described in .
This document provides an informational reference in describing the role of SDP and the Offer/Answer exchange mechanism for the most common WebRTC use-cases.
This SDP examples provided in this document is still a work in progress, but it aims to align closest to the evolving standards work.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Javascript Session Exchange Protocol(JSEP) specifies a generic protocol needed to generate Offers and Answers negotiated between the WebRTC peers for setting up, updating and tearing down a WebRTC session. For this purpose, SDP is used to construct Offers/Answers for describing (media and non-media) streams as appropriate for the recipients of the session description to participate in the session.

The remainder of this document is organized as follows: Sections 3 and 4 provides an overview of SDP and the Offer/Answer exchange mechanism. Section 5 provides sample SDP generated for the most common WebRTC use-cases.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: SDP and the WebRTC
section.t: The purpose of this section is to provide a general overview of SDP and its components. For a more in-depth understanding, the readers are advised to refer to .

The Session Description Protocol (SDP) describes multimedia sessions, which can contain audio, video, whiteboard, fax, modem, and other streams. SDP provides a general purpose, standard representation to describe various aspects of multimedia session such as media capabilities, transport addresses and related metadata in a transport agnostic manner, for the purposes of session announcement, session invitation and parameter negotiation.
As of today SDP is widely used in the context of Session Initiation Protocol , Real-time Transport Protocol and Real-time Streaming Protocol applications .

Below figure introduces high-level breakup of SDP into components that semantically describe a multimedia session, in our case, a WebRTC session . It by no means captures everything about SDP and hence, should be used for informational purposes only.

proposes JavaScript application to fully specify and control the signaling plane of a multimedia session as described in the JSEP specification . JSEP provides mechanisms to create session characterization and media definition information to conduct the session based on SDP exchanges.

In this context, SDP serves two purposes:
Provide grammatical structure syntactically. Semantically convey partipant's intention and capabilities required to successfully negotiate a session.

section.title: Offer/Answer and the WebRTC
section.t: This section introduces SDP Offer/Answer Exchange mechanism mandated by WebRTC for negotiating session capabilities while setting up, updating and tearing down a WebRTC session. This section is intentionally brief in nature and interested readers are recommended to refer for specific details on the protocol operation.

The Offer/Answer model specifies rule for the bilateral exchange of Session Description Protocol (SDP) messages for creation of multimedia streams. It defines protocol with involved participants exchanging desired session characteristics from each others perspective constructed as SDP to negotiate the session between them.

In the most basic form,the protocol operation begins by one of the participants sending an initial SDP Offer describing its intent to start a multimedia communication session. The participant receiving the offer MAY generate an SDP Answer accepting the offer or it MAY reject the offer. If the session is accepted the Offer/Answer model guarantees a common view of the multimedia session between the participants.
At any time, either participant MAY generate a new SDP offer that updates the session in progress.

With in the context of WebRTC, the Offer/Answer model defines the state-machinery for WebRTC peers to negotiate session descriptions between them during the initial setup stages as well as for eventual session updates. Javascript Session Establishment Protocol specification for WebRTC provides the mechanism for generating SDP Offers and Answers in order for both sides of the session to agree upon details such as list of media formats to be sent/received, bandwidth information, crypto parameters, transport parameters, for example.

section.title: WebRTC Session Description Examples
section.t: A typical web based real-time multimedia communication session can be characterized as below:

list.t: It has zero or more Audio only, Video only or Audio/Video RTP Sessions,
MAY contain zero or more non-media data sessions,
All the sessions are secured with DTLS-SRTP,
Supports NAT traversal using ICE mechanism,
Sessions can be over IPv4-only, IPv6-only, dual-stack based clients.

section.title: Some Conventions
section.t: The examples given in this document follow the conventions listed below:

list.t: In all the examples, Alice and Bob are assumed to be the WebRTC peers.
support for multiplexing several media streams over a single underlying transport is assumed by default unless explicitly specified otherwise.
Call flow diagrams that accompany the use-cases capture only the prominent aspects of the system behavior and intentionally is not detailed to improve readability.

The SDP examples deviate from actual on-the-wire SDP notation in several ways. This is done to facilitate readability and to conform to the restrictionsimposed by the RFC formatting rules.
Any SDP line that is indented (compared to the initial line in the SDP block) is a continuation of the preceding line. The line break and indent are to be interpreted as a single space character.
Empty lines in any SDP example are inserted to make functional divisions in the SDP clearer, and are not actually part of the SDP syntax.
Excepting the above two conventions, line endings are to be interpreted as <CR><LF> pairs (that is, an ASCII 13 followed by an ASCII 10).

Against each SDP line, pointers to the appropriate RFCs are provide for further informational reference. Also an attempt has been made to provide explanatory notes to enable better understanding of the SDP usage, wherever appropriate.

Following SDP details are common across all the use-cases defined in this document unless mentioned otherwise.
DTLS fingerprint for SRTP (a=fingerprint) RTP/RTCP Multiplexing (a=rtcp-mux) RTCP Feedback support (a=rtcp-fb) Host and server-reflexive candidate lines (a=candidate) SRTP Setup framework parameters (a=setup) RTCP attribute (a=rtcp) RTP header extension indicating audio-levels from client to the mixer
For more details, readers are recommended to refer to specification.
The term "Session" is used rather loosely in this document to refer to either a "Communication Session" or a "RTP Session" or a "RTP Stream" depending on the context.
Payload type 109 is usually used for OPUS, 0 for PCMU, 8 for PCMA, 99 for H.264 and 120 for VP8 in most of the examples to maintain uniformity.
In the actual use the values that represent SSRCs, ICE candidate foundations, WebRTC Mediastream and MediaStreamTrack Ids shall be much larger and random than the ones shown in the examples.
[OPEN ISSUE-1]: SDP Examples for Data Channel, Simulcast, SVC are still being discussed and doesn't represent the final solution.

section.title: Audio Only Session
section.t: This common scenario shows SDP for secure two-way audio session with Alice offering Opus, PCMU, PCMA and Bob accepting all the offered audio codecs.

texttable.title: 5.2.1 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Alice supports RTP header extension to indicate audio levels
- Alice can send and recv audio
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives
- Alice can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 54609
- Alice intends to use reduced size RTCP for this session

texttable.title: 5.2.1 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Bob supports audio level RTP header extension as well
- Bob can send and recv audio
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel
- Bob can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 49203
- RTP Host ICE Candidate for Opus Stream
- Bob intends to use reduced size RTCP for this session

section.title: Audio/Video Session
section.t: Alice and Bob establish a two-way audio and video session with Opus as the audio codec and H.264 as the video codec.

texttable.title: 5.2.2 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Alice can send and recv audio
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives
- Alice can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 54609
- Alice intends to use reduced size RTCP for this session
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
- Alice can send and recv video
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives
- Alice can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 62537
- Indicates support for Picture loss Indication and NACK
- Full Intra Frame Request-Codec Control Message support
- Indicates support for Picture loss Indication and NACK
- Full Intra Frame Request-Codec Control Message support
- Alice intends to use reduced size RTCP for this session

texttable.title: 5.2.2 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Bob can send and recv audio
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel
- Bob can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 49203
- RTP Host ICE Candidate for Opus Stream
- Bob intends to use reduced size RTCP for this session
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
- Bob can send and recv video
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel
- Bob can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 63130
- Host ICE Candidate for Opus Stream
- Server Reflexive ICE Candidate for the above host candidate
- Server Reflexive Candidate for the Second Host Candidate
- Indicates support for NACK based RTCP feedback
- Indicates support for Picture loss Indication and NACK
- Full Intra Frame Request- Codec Control Message support
- Bob intends to use reduced size RTCP for this session

section.title: Data Only Session
section.t: This scenario illustrates SDP negotiated to setup a data-only session based on SCTP Data Channel, thus enabling use-cases such as file-transfer for example.

texttable.title: 5.2.3 SDP Offer
texttable.c: - Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives
- Alice can send and recv non-media data

texttable.title: 5.2.3 SDP Answer
texttable.c: - Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel
- Bob can send and recv non-media data

section.title: Audio Call On Hold
section.t: Alice calls Bob, but when Bob answers he places Alice on hold by setting the SDP direction attribute to a=sendonly in the Answer.

texttable.title: 5.2.4 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Alice can send and recv audio
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives
- Alice can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 54609

texttable.title: 5.2.4 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel
- Bob can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 49203

section.title: Audio with DTMF Session
section.t: In this example, Alice wishes to establish two separate audio streams, one for normal audio and the other for telephone-events. Alice offers first audio stream with three codecs and the other with tones (for DTMF). Bob accepts both the audio streams by choosing Opus as the audio codec and telephone-event for the other stream.

figure.artwork:
Audio Session with DTMF
Alice Bob | | | | | | | Offer(Audio:Opus,PCMU,PCMA Audio:telephone-event)| |-------------------------------------------------->| | | | | | Answer(Audio:Opus, Audio:telephone-event) | |<--------------------------------------------------| | | | | | Opus audio stream and telephone-event stream | |...................................................| | |

texttable.title: 5.2.5 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Alice can send and recv audio
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives
- Alice can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 54609
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives

texttable.title: 5.2.5 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Bob can send and receive Opus audio
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel
- Bob can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 49203
- Alice intends to use reduced size RTCP for this session
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel
- Alice can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 54690
- Alice intends to use reduced size RTCP for this session

section.title: One Way Audio/Video Session - Document Camera
section.t: In this scenario Alice and Bob engage in a 1 way audio and video session with Bob receiving Alice's audio and her presentation slides as video stream.

figure.artwork:
1 Way Audio & Video Session - Document Camera
Alice Bob | | | | | | | Alice Offers sendonly audio and video streams. | | The video stream corresponds to her presentation | | | | Offer(Audio:Opus, Video: VP8) | |----------------------------------------------------->| | | | | | (Audio:Opus, Video: VP8) | |<-----------------------------------------------------| | | | | | One-way Opus Audio, VP8 Video | |......................................................| | Bob can hear Alice and see her presentation slides.| | | | |

texttable.title: 5.2.6 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives

texttable.title: 5.2.6 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel

section.title: Audio, Video Session with BUNDLE Support Unknown
section.t:
In this example, since Alice is unsure of the Bob's support of the BUNDLE framework, following 3 step procedures are performed in order to negotiate and setup a BUNDLE Address for the session
An SDP Offer, in which the Alice assigns unique addresses to each "m=" line in the BUNDLE group, and requests the Answerer to select the Offerer's BUNDLE address. An SDP Answer, in which the Bob indicates its support for BUNDLE, and assigns its own BUNDLE address for the BUNDLED m= lines. A subsequent SDP Offer from Alice, which is used to perform BUNDLE Address Synchronization (BAS).
Once the Offer/Answer exchange completes, both Alice and Bob each end up using single RTP Session for both the Media Streams.

figure.artwork:
2-Way Secure Audio,Video with BUNDLE support unknown
Alice Bob | | | | |Alice offers BUNDLE support with unique address | |for the audio and video m-line | | | | | | Offer(Audio:Opus Video:VP8) | |----------------------------------------------------->| | |Bob | |supports | |BUNDLE | Answer(Audio:Opus Video:VP8) | |<-----------------------------------------------------| | | | |Bob uses | |identical | |addresses | | | Updated Offer for Bundle Address Synchronization. | |----------------------------------------------------->| | | | | | Answer (Bob accepts the updated offer) | |<-----------------------------------------------------| | | | | | 2 Way Call with Audio and Video Multiplexed | |......................................................| | |

texttable.title: 5.2.7 SDP Offer w/BUNDLE
texttable.c: Alice supports grouping of m=lines under BUNDLE semantics
Audio m=line part of BUNDLE group with a unique port number
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives
Video m=line part of the Bundle group with a unique port number
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives

texttable.title: 5.2.7 SDP Answer w/BUNDLE
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Audio m=line part of the BUNDLE group
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel
Video m=line part of the BUNDLE group with the port from audio line repeated
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel

texttable.title: 5.2.7 SDP Offer for BAS
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Port number finalized as Bundle Address.
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)

section.title: Audio, Video and Data Session
section.t: This example shows SDP for negotiating a session with Audio, Video and data streams between Alice and Bob with BUNDLE support known.

figure.artwork:
Audio, Video, Data with BUNDLE support known
Alice Bob | | | | |Alice indicates BUNDLE support with | |identical address across all the m=lines | | | | | | Offer(Audio:Opus Video:VP8 Data) | |------------------------------------------->| | |Bob does | |the same | Answer(Audio:Opus,Video:VP8 Data) | |<-------------------------------------------| | | | | | | | Two-way Audio,Video, Data multiplexed | |............................................| | | | |

texttable.title: 5.2.8 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)

texttable.title: 5.2.8 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Bob's trickle support support is indicated at the session level
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)

section.title: Audio, Video Session with BUNDLE Unsupported
section.t: This use-case illustrates SDP Offer/Answer exchange where the far-end (Bob) either doesn't support media bundling or doesn't want to group m=lines over a single 5-tuple.
On successful Offer/Answer exchange, Alice and Bob each end up using unique 5-tuple for audio and video media streams respectively.

figure.artwork:
2-Way Secure Audio,Video with BUNDLE Unsupported
Alice Bob | | | | |Alice offers BUNDLE support with unique address | |for the audio and video m-line | | | | | | Offer(Audio:Opus Video:VP8) | |----------------------------------------------------->| | | | |Bob doesn't | |support | |BUNDLE | Answer(Audio:Opus Video:VP8) | |<-----------------------------------------------------| | |Bob uses | |unique | |addresses | |across the | |m=lines | | |2Way Call with Audio and Video on different 5-tuples | |......................................................| | | | |

texttable.title: 5.2.9 SDP Offer w/BUNDLE
texttable.c: Alice supports grouping of m=lines under BUNDLE semantics
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Audio m=line part of BUNDLE group with a unique port number
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
Video m=line part of the BUNDLE group with a unique port number
- Alice can perform DTLS before Answer arrives

texttable.title: 5.2.9 SDP Answer without BUNDLE
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
- Bob carries out DTLS Handshake in parallel

section.title: Audio, Video BUNDLED, but Data (Not BUNDLED)
section.t: This example show-cases SDP for negotiating a session with Audio, Video and data streams between Alice and Bob with data stream not being part of the BUNDLE group. This is shown by assigning unique port for data media sections.

figure.artwork:
Audio, Video, with Data (Not in BUNDLE)
Alice Bob | | | | |Alice wants to multiplex audio, video but not data | | | | | | Offer(Audio:Opus Video:VP8, Data(not in BUNDLE)) | |----------------------------------------------------->| | | | | | Answer(Audio:Opus Video:VP8, Data) | |<-----------------------------------------------------| | | | | |2 Way Call with Audio, Video Multiplexed except data | |......................................................| | |

texttable.title: 5.2.10 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Alice wants to BUNDLE only audio and video media.
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)

texttable.title: 5.2.10 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)

section.title: Audio Only, Add Video to BUNDLE
section.t: This example involves 2 Offer/Answer exchanges. First one setting up Audio-only session followed by an updated Offer/Answer exchange to add video stream to the ongoing session. Also the newly added video stream is BUNDLED with the audio stream.

figure.artwork:
Audio Only , Add Video and BUNDLE
Alice Bob | | | | | Alice indicates support for BUNDLE | | | | Offer(Audio:Opus) | |----------------------------------------------------->| | | | |Bob supports | |BUNDLE | Answer(Audio:Opus) | |<-----------------------------------------------------| | |Alice adds | |video stream | Updated Offer(Audio:Opus, Video:VP8) |to BUNDLE |----------------------------------------------------->| | | | |Bob accepts | Updated Answer(Audio:Opus, Video:VP8) | |<-----------------------------------------------------| | | | 2Way Call with Audio and Video Multiplexed | |......................................................| | | | |

texttable.title: 5.2.11 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Alice wants to BUNDLE only audio and video media.
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)

texttable.title: 5.2.10 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)

texttable.title: 5.2.11 SDP Updated Offer
texttable.c: Alice wants to BUNDLE only audio and video media.
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)

texttable.title: 5.2.11 SDP Updated Answer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)

section.title: MultiResolution, RTX, FEC Examples
section.t: This section deals with scenarios related to multi-source, multi-stream negotiation such as layered coding, simulcast, along with techniques that deal with providing robustness against transmission errors such as FEC and RTX. Also to note, mechanisms such as FEC and RTX could be envisioned in the above basic scenarios as well.

section.title: Sendonly Simulcast Session with 2 cameras and 2 encodings per camera
section.t: The SDP below shows Offer/Answer exchange with one audio and two video sources. Each of the video source can be sent at two different resolutions.
One video source corresponds to VP8 encoding, while the other corresponds to H.264 encoding.
bundle-only framework is used along with BUNDLE grouping framework to enable multiplexing of all the 5 streams (1 audio stream + 4 video streams) over a single RTP Session.

figure.artwork:
1 Way Successful Simulcast w/BUNDLE
Alice Bob | | | | | Alice offers 2 sendonly video sources | | with 2 simulcast encodings per source | | and bundle-only for video | | | | | | Offer(Audio:Opus,Video1:VP8,Video2:H.264) | |------------------------------------------------>| | | | | | Answer(Audio:Opus Video1:VP8,Video2:H.264) | |<------------------------------------------------| | | |One-Way 1 Opus, 2 H.264 and 2 VP8 video streams, | | all multiplexed | |.................................................| | | | |

texttable.title: 5.3.1 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Alice supports grouping of m=lines under BUNDLE semantics
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
bundle-only video line with port number set to zero
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
Video m=line part of BUNDLE group
bundle-only video line with port number set to zero
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tc)
Video m=line part of BUNDLE group

texttable.title: 5.3.1 SDP Anwer
texttable.c: Alice supports grouping of m=lines under BUNDLE semantics
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
a=candidate:1 2 UDP 694302207 98.248.92.77 49203 typ srflx raddr 192.168.1.4 rport 49203
BUNDLE accepted with port repeated from the audio port
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
Video m=line part of BUNDLE group
BUNDLE accepted with port repeated from the audio port
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tc)
Video m=line part of BUNDLE group
Bob accepts to receieve the offered simulcast streams

section.title: Successful SVC Video Session
section.t: This section shows an SDP Offer/Answer for a session with an audio and a single video source. The video source is encoded as layered coding at 3 different resolutions based on . The video m=line shows 3 streams with last stream (payload 100) dependent on streams with payload 96 and 97 for decoding.

figure.artwork:
SVC Session - 3 Layers w/BUNDLE
Alice Bob | | | | | Alice offers 3 sendonly video streams | | as 3 layers of SVC and bundle-only | | for video streams. | | | | Offer(Video:H.264 SVC) | |------------------------------------------------>| | | | |Bob accepts Alice's | |offered Codec | |operation points | | | Answer(Video:H.264) | |<------------------------------------------------| | | |One-Way H.264 SVC video streams | |.................................................| | | | |

texttable.title: 5.3.2 SDP Offer with SVC
texttable.c: Alice supports grouping of m=lines under BUNDLE semantics
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Audio m=line part of BUNDLE group with a unique port number
bundle-only video line with port number set to zero
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tc)
Audio m=line part of BUNDLE group

texttable.title: 5.3.2 SDP Answer with SVC
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
BUNDLE accepted Bundle address same as audio m=line.
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
Video m=line part of BUNDLE group

section.title: Successful 1-way Simulcast Sessio with 2 resolutions and RTX - One resolution rejected
section.t: This section shows an SDP Offer/Answer exchange for a simulcast scenario with 2 two resolutions.
It also showcases when Bob rejects one of the Simulcast Video Stream which results in the rejection of the associated repair stream implicitly.

figure.artwork:
Simulcast Streams with Retransmission Rejected
Alice Bob | | | | |Alice offers single audio and simulcasted video streams | | with bundle-only for video | | | | | |Offer(Audio:Opus Video:VP8 with 2 resolutions,RTX Stream)| |-------------------------------------------------------->| | | | |Bob accepts 1 | |simulcast,rtx | |rejects the | |other | Answer(Audio:Opus Video:VP8 with 1 res & RTX Stream) | |<--------------------------------------------------------| | | | | |1-way audio,video session and its associated RTX stream, | | all multiplexed | |.........................................................| | | | |

texttable.title: 5.3.4 SDP Offer w/Simulcast, RTX
texttable.c: Alice supports grouping of m=lines under BUNDLE semantics

bundle-only video line with port number set to zero
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)

texttable.c: Alice supports grouping of m=lines under BUNDLE semantics
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
BUNDLE accepted with Bundle address identical to audio m-line
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
Bob accepts only one simulcast resolution

section.title: Simulcast Video Session with Forward Error Correction
section.t: This section shows an SDP Offer/Answer exchange for Simulcast video stream at two resolutions and and has style FEC flows.
On completion of the Offer/Answer exchange mechanism we end up one audio stream, 2 simulcast video streams and 2 associated FEC streams are sent over a single 5-tuple.

figure.artwork:
Simulcast Streams with Forward Error Correction
Alice Bob | | | | | | |Alice offers single audio and simulcasted video streams | |with bundle-only | | | | | |Offer(Audio:Opus Video:VP8 with 2 resolutions with FEC Streams)| |-------------------------------------------------------------->| | | | |Bob | |accepts | |Alice's | |offer |Answer(Audio:Opus Video:VP8 with 2 resolutions w/FEC Streams) | |<--------------------------------------------------------------| | | |One-Way Audio,Video session with 4 video streams(Simulcast | | and FEC) all multiplexed | |...............................................................| | | | | | |

texttable.title: 5.3.5 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Alice supports grouping of m=lines under BUNDLE semantics
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
bundle-only video line with port number set to zero
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
Video m=line part of BUNDLE group

texttable.title: 5.3.5 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
Audio m=line part of BUNDLE group with a unique port number
BUNDLE accepted with Bundle Address identical to audio m=line.
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
Video m=line part of BUNDLE group

section.title: Others
section.t: The examples in the section provide SDP for a variety of scenarios related to RTP Header extension, Legacy Interop scenarios and more.

section.title: Audio Session - Voice Activity Detection
section.t: This example shows Alice indicating the support of the RTP header extension to include the audio-level of the audio sample carried in the RTP packet.

figure.artwork:
2-Way Audio with VAD
Alice Bob | | | | |Alice indicates support for including | |audio level in RTP header | | | | Offer(Audio:Opus,PCMU,PCMA) | |---------------------------------------->| | | | | | Answer(Audio:Opus,PCMU,PCMA) | |<----------------------------------------| | | | |Bob accepts and | |indicates his | |support as well | | | Two way Opus Audio | |.........................................| | | |Per packet audio-level is included in the| |RTP header | | |

texttable.title: 5.4.1 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)

texttable.title: 5.4.1 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Bob can send and recv audio
- Bob can perform RTP/RTCP Muxing on port 49203

section.title: Audio Conference - Voice Activity Detection
section.t: This example shows SDP for RTP header extension that allows RTP-level mixers in audio conferences to deliver information about the audio level of individual participants.

figure.artwork:
Audio Conference with VAD Support
Alice Mixer | | |Alice indicates her interest to audio | |levels for the contributing sources | | | |Offer(Audio:Opus,PCMU,PCMA) | |---------------------------------------->| | | | | |Answer(Audio:Opus,PCMU,PCMA) | |<----------------------------------------| | | | |Mixer indicates | |it can provide | |audio-levels |Two way Opus Audio | |.........................................| | | |Audio-levels per CSRCS is included in the| |RTP header | | |

texttable.title: 5.4.2 SDP Offer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
- Alice can send and recv audio

texttable.title: 5.4.2 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)

section.title: Successful legacy Interop Fallaback with bundle-only
section.t:
In the scenario described below, Alice is a multi-stream capable WebRTC endpoint while Bob is a legacy VOIP end-point. The SDP Offer/Answer exchange demonstrates successful session setup with fallback to audio only stream negotiated via bundle-only framework between the end-points. Specifically,
Offer from Alice describes 2 cameras via 2 video m=lines with both marked as bundle-only. Since Bob doesnot recognize either the BUNDLE mechanism or the bundle-only attribute, he accepts only the audio stream from Alice.

figure.artwork:
Successful 2-Way WebRTC <-> VOIP Interop
Alice Bob | | | | | Alice is a multistream capable WebRTC end-point | | & Bob is behind a legacy VOIP system | | | |Offer(Audio:Opus Video:2 VP8,2 H2.64 Streams) with | | bundle-only | |---------------------------------------------------------->| | Alice marks both the video streams as bundle-only | | | | | | Answer(Audio:Opus) | |<----------------------------------------------------------| | |Bob | |accepts | |audio | |stream, | |since he | |doesn't | |recognize | |bundle-only | | | Two way Opus Audio | |...........................................................| | | | |

texttable.title: 5.4.3 SDP Simulcast bundle-only
texttable.c: Alice supports grouping of m=lines under BUNDLE semantics
Audio m=line part of BUNDLE group with a unique port number
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (ta)
bundle-only video line with port number set to zero
Video m=line part of BUNDLE group
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tb)
bundle-only video line with port number set to zero
Video m=line part of BUNDLE group
Identifies RTCMediaStream ID (ma) and RTCMediaStreamTrack ID (tc)

texttable.title: 5.4.3 SDP Anwer
texttable.c: a=candidate:1 1 UDP 694302207 98.248.92.77 49203 typ srflx raddr 192.168.1.7 rport 49203
Bob doesn't recognize bundle-only and hence rejects the video stream
Bob doesn't recognize bundle-only and hence rejects the video stream

section.title: Legacy Interop with RTP/AVP profile
section.t: In this section, we attempt to provide session descriptions showcasing inter-operability between a WebRTC end-point and a Legacy VOIP end-point. The ideas included in here are not fully baked into the standards and might be controversial in nature. The hope here is to demonstrate a plausible SDP composition to enchance seamless inter-operability between the aforementioned communication systems.

In the scenario desribed below, Alice is a legacy end-point which sends Offer with two sets of media descriptions per media type.
One set that correponds to compliant UDP/TLS/RTP/SAVPF based audio and video descriptions.
Another set with RTP/AVP based audio and video descriptions for the legacy Interop purposes.
Also to note, Alice includes session level DTLS information and media level RTCP feedback information as applicable to both the sets of media descriptions

On the other hand, Bob being a WebRTC end-point, recognizes accepts the media descriptions with RTP/AVP profile. The security and feedback requirements for the session are either handled by a intermediate gateway or with some combination of Alice's capabilities and the intermediate gateway.

figure.artwork:
Successful 2-Way WebRTC <-> VOIP Interop
Alice Bob | | | | | Alice is a legacy VOIP End-point & Bob is a WebRTC End-Point | | | | | | | | Offer(Audio:Opus Video:H.264) | |-------------------------------------------------------------->| | | | | |Alice includes 2 copies of media descriptions | |1. WebRTC compliant media description (UDP/TLS/RTP/SAVPF) | |2. Legacy compliant media description (RTP/AVP) | | | | | | Answer(Audio:Opus, Video:H.264) | |<--------------------------------------------------------------| | |Bob | |accepts | |"legacy | |compliant" | |m=line | | | | | Two way Opus Audio, H.264 Video | |...............................................................| | Session also suports RTP/RTCP Mux, RTCP Feedback | | |

texttable.title: 5.4.5 SDP Offer
texttable.c: These set of media descriptions are for Legacy Inter-op purposes
Alice includes RTP/AVP audio stream description
Alice still includes RTP/RTCP Mux support
She adds her intent for NACK RTCP feedback support
Alice includes RTP/AVP video stream description
Alice intends to perform RTP/RTCP Mux
Alice indicates support for Picture loss Indication and NACK RTCP feedback

texttable.title: 5.4.5 SDP Answer
texttable.c: Bob accepts RTP/AVP based audio stream
Bob accepts RTP/AVP based video stram

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document requires no actions from IANA.

section.title: Acknowledgments
section.t: We would like to thanks Justin Uberti, Chris Flo for their detailed review and inputs.

section.title: Change Log
section.t: [RFC EDITOR NOTE: Please remove this section when publishing]

Changes from draft-nandakumar-rtcweb-sdp-05
Added Ascii chart for all the SDP Eaxamples Improved text and updated SDP Examples for Simulcast and FEC Fixed MediaStream ID Semantics SDP Errors

Changes from draft-nandakumar-rtcweb-sdp-04
Interim version of the draft to avert expiry Corrected placement of c= line as per RFC4566 Updated simulcast SDP to reflect draft-westerlund-avtcore-rtp-simulcast-04

Changes from draft-nandakumar-rtcweb-sdp-03
Aligned more closely with JSEP version -05 Added Conventions to help readability Add more examples to clarify BUNDLE use-cases

Changes from draft-nandakumar-rtcweb-sdp-02
Major refactoring was done to group the examples in to categories SDP was updated through out to reflect JSEP-04 style of defining attributes per m=line than at the session level. Added 8 new examples. Updated references for Trickle, Unified Plan Add section to explain the syntax conventions followed in the examples.

Changes from draft-nandakumar-rtcweb-sdp-01
Updated references to OPUS RTP Payload Specification. Updated BUNDLE examples based on the latest draft-ietf-mmusic-sdp-bundle-negotiation. Added examples for multiple audio and video flows based on Unified Plan. Added new examples for RTX and FEC streams Updated Simulcast and SVC examples

Changes from draft-nandakumar-rtcweb-sdp-00
Fixed editorial comments on the mailing list. Updated Data-channel SDP information based on draft-ietf-mmusic-sctp-sdp. Updated BUNDLE examples based on draft-ietf-mmusic-sdp-bundle-negotiation. Added examples for few more BUNDLE variants Added new examples for Simulcast and SVC
